and (
) Purpose: IRM

contains instructions for the Cincinnati Centralized Innocent Spouse Operation (CCISO) for processing innocent spouse cases after a request for relief is fully allowed, partially allowed, or disallowed. In addition, this IRM includes instructions for processing cases after a request innocent spouse relief is determined to be non-qualifying. See IRM
, Non-Qualifying Requests for Relief & Complex Account Issues, for more infor- mation. (
) Audience: Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) Division employees in CCISO processing ﬁnal determinations of innocent spouse relief on taxpayer accounts. (
) Policy Owner: The innocent spouse program is under the jurisdiction of the SB/SE Division Director, Examination - Field and Campus Policy. (
) Program Owner: The program owner is SB/SE Campus Exam and Field Support. (
) Program Goals: The program goals are to timely and accurately process
, Request for Innocent Spouse Relief, determinations. (
) The innocent spouse program makes determinations on requests for relief provided in the Code of Federal Regulation (CFR) Title
, Subtitle F - Procedure and Administration, IRC
, Relief from Joint and Several Liability on Joint Return, and CFR Title
, Subtitle A – Income Taxes, IRC
, Treatment of Community Income. (
) An innocent spouse technician applies the law to the facts and circumstances submitted with Form
, to determine whether the individual should be relieved of any or all tax liability owed. See IRM
, Technical Provisions of IRC
, or IRM
, Relief from Community Property Laws, for more information. (

) CCISO handles all requests except those involving tax years with open audits conducted by a Revenue Agent or Tax Compliance Officer outside of the campus environment. In the case of open ﬁeld examination audits, determina- tions will be made by the assigned employee. (
) The campus Innocent Spouse Program is an Examination Field Support Operation located at CCISO. (

) All requests for account adjustment(s) and/or refunds will be submitted to CCISO processors on an Innocent Spouse Operations (ISO) Adjustment Request (ISO-AR) with a full TXMOD print of the account attached. (
) The procedures in this IRM are general in nature and cannot cover all situa- tions that may be encountered. Document all actions taken and consult with management when appropriate. (

The following is a list of common terms used in this IRM section:

Term Description Area Offices Geographical subdivisions of Field Examination. Area Office Examiners Revenue Agents or Tax Compli- ance Officers working in Field Examination. Area Office Innocent Spouse Co- ordinator The employee in Planning and Special Programs (PSP) assigned the innocent spouse program for the Field Examination Area. Audit Information Management System (AIMS) The database used by Examina- tion to track cases from inception to completion through various status codes and other data. Command Code A code input into IDRS to access or update taxpayer data. Deﬁner Typically an alphabetic character added to the end of a Command Code to access or update different aspects of data. Determinations With regard to innocent spouse relief, the Service determines whether to allow relief in full, in part, or deny relief, based on the application of the facts to the law under IRC 6015, Relief from joint and several liability on joint return, or under IRC 66(c) for relief from Community Property laws. First Read The teams located in CCISO that are responsible for screening relief requests, and building or non-qualifying requests as appli- cable. Full Scope CCISO teams of Financial Techni- cians (FT) that are responsible for making determinations of relief based on the facts applied to the law of each tax year request.
With regard to innocent spouse relief, the Service determines whether to allow relief in full, in part, or deny relief, based on the application of the facts to the law under IRC
, Relief from joint and several liability on joint return, or under IRC
(c) for relief from Community Property laws.
The stage shown on ISTS indicates the status of the request for relief. For instance, Stage
indicates the date the request was received by the Service. See IRM
, Innocent Spouse Tracking System, for more infor- mation.

25.15 Relief from Joint and Several Liability
Allowed Relief (

) A request is considered to be partially allowed if the RS is still liable for any part of an original ﬁling or additional tax assessment (including EITC reversal, withholding credit, accuracy-related penalty, etc.). Allowed Relief - (

) A tax adjustment can be made to reduce the liability for one taxpayer while leaving the other taxpayer fully liable for the balance due via mirrored accounts. a. Verify the ISO-AR requesting a tax adjustment be made to the RS’ MFT

module. An allocation worksheet should be attached to the ISO-AR. Verify the information on the allocation worksheet(s) matches the infor- mation on the ISO-AR, i.e. tax, withholding, credit transaction codes, penalty codes, and amounts to be adjusted. b. If there is an underpayment and an understatement, and partial relief being granted for each, there will be two allocation worksheets attached to the ISO-AR. c. There are some circumstances in which an allocation may not be required. Example: RS is granted full relief of the original underpayment, but denied relief of the understatement. Since we are not separat- ing the individual tax posting, it is not necessary to allocate. Exception: If the understatement portion is strictly a math error, there not be an allocation worksheet for this amount. Example: The math error amount can be determined by comparing the TC
tax amount and the “TX/TRPR>” amount under the Posted Return Information on TXMOD. If the TC

amount higher, then the difference between the two ﬁgures is the math error understatement amount. d. ) The section describes how account problems are processed. (

) An account problem may be identiﬁed by either First Read or Full Scope researching the taxpayers’ account. Account problems can include math errors from the original return processing, duplicate assessments, missing/incorrectly applied payments, incorrect/incomplete tax assessments made by the Exami- nation or AUR operations or Form
-X, Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, for Accounts Management adjustments. (
) The ISO-AR identiﬁes the account issue. The ISO-AR must clearly explain what the problem is and what action the processor must take. (

) The Financial Technician must send back-up documentation to justify the actions requested, e.g., copy of the tax return, substantiation for math error, proof of payment. The Financial Technician may or may not send the entire case ﬁle. (
) The processor will review ISO-AR for completeness and take the necessary actions to resolve the account problems. (
